wnHEErptRfc:
when I was a little girl I was
completely obsessed with candy I remember constantly begging my dad for
a dollar so I could get on my bike race as fast as I could to our local
convenience store where I would purchase as much candy as I possibly could for

Stephen Hegg: This is what legalized marijuana
looks like—and smells like—most of the time. But not all pot is going up in smoke. Welcome to the brand whole new world of cannabis-infused
foods and drinks--edibles. Medical marijuana dispensaries, like the Have
a Heart Collective in Seattle’s U District, have been serving them up for years to patients. Cupcakes, chews, candies, sodas, and of course
the candy bar. Quiwaan Little: This is the Evergreen Herbal
chocolate bar. They come in an array of flavors. This one right here is the dark chocolate
popping candy Marco Hoffman: We’re talking about 300-400
percent increase in sales overnight. Marc Hoffman, owner of Evergreen Herbal. Hegg: Across town, Marco Hoffman’s company
across town in Sodo, Marco Hoffman‘s company, Evergreen Herbal, is converting a medical
marijuana processing facility to make goodies for the recreational market. The two operations have to be completely separate. Hoffman: This is our Strawberry Quencher,
its strawberry lemonade. These are our 65mg bars. We’ve got green tea, sleepy time tea, black
tea and chai tea. A wonderful accompanying product is our honey
stick. We can basically put cannabis in just about
any product. The possibilities are endless. Hegg: But eating pot is a completely different
experience than smoking it. Mary White: You’ve got to know actually
more about edibles than you need to know just about pot. Hegg: Mary White grows pot for medicinal use,
makes her own edibles, and gives classes on how to cook deliciously with marijuana. Mary White, a medical cannabis user and cook,
inspects her personal plants with producer Stephen Hegg. White: The thing about eating pot, of course,
is that you have to wait at least a half an hour or forty-five minutes, and if you don’t,
that’s when people eat too much. You eat a cookie and go ‘oh I don’t feel
anything’ and you eat another one and an hour later you’re sucking your thumb in
a corner. If you are thinking about using cannabis in
an edible form you have to really ask questions. Hegg: Questions the state liquor control board
is trying to answer with regulations, Rick Garza: It’s important than anyone who
is an adult user understand the product that they’re consuming, and then I think a real
concern for us is keeping it out of the hands of children. Hegg: It’s a new world of product safety. Garza: What does it look like, what should
the serving sizes be, what should the concentrations be, how much THC should you allow be in a
serving size, in a product? Hegg: The liquor control board started with
dosage--controlling levels of THC-- tetrahydrocannabinol-- marijuana’s main psychoactive ingredient. The levels are tested and reported, from raw
product through the different stages of oil extraction, and product infusion. Washington’s rules limit any one product
to a THC maximum of 100 mg. Solid edibles, like candy bars, must be sectioned
into pieces containing no more than 10mg. Marijuana infused chocolate bars, from Evergreen
Herbal, labelled with 65mg of THC. Hoffman: Holding a chocolate bar that has
100mg of THC is the equivalent of holding a fifth of whiskey. You would not consume it all at once. It would be insanity. Tim Moxey: I think there’s a degree of responsibility
that the consumer has to take on about having some awareness as to what would be too much. And passing that onto the consumer is helpful
advice. It is education. And if you know what 10mg is, 10mg should
be okay for a lot of people. Hegg: English entrepreneur Tim Moxey moved
to Seattle with his young family to start a cannabis bakery business. Moxey sees huge potential in single low dose
servings. Moxey: Small cookies or brownie bites that
are low in THC dose, so for about 4mg up to 10. Then experience would be similar to a glass
and a half of wine. Cherylynne Crowther: We really are opening
a brand new world. We have to be really careful and recognize
this is a drug packaged in a sweet. Hegg: And the enticing world of edibles is
not one Cherylynne Crowther is ready for. She’s a mom and a volunteer with a community
coalition addressing underage substance abuse. Crowther: The more access adults have, the
more access kids have. Seattle Public Schools are for the first time
seeing edibles that they’re confiscating them, and they’re in the form of highly
desirable to kids. Hegg: That’s the liquor board’s other
major concern as it regulates products and labeling. Garza: As it relates to edibles, nothing can
be especially appealing to children. Nothing with cartoons, nothing with toys,
nothing that depicts children. Hegg: Banned are any “cute” products—gummy
bears, jelly beans or product knock- offs. Hoffman: The edible market, in general, or
I-502 actually, is one of the most regulated industries in the country, so it’s going
to be a safe, you’re going to have safe product line, you’re going to have consistency
in the products, you’re going to have people who really know what they’re doing. So I think it’s going to be a very well-received
by the end user, absolutely.

9eUIhvGKKiI:
Hey there! Welcome to Life Noggin! Oh there's a fog rolling in! Wait a minute! [Blocko Sniffs] That's not fog! People have been using cannabis as a sleep
aid for decades, mainly due to the feeling of relaxation and calm it’s commonly associated
with. And many believe that it can even help with
sleep disorders. Studies evaluating the effect of cannabis
on sleep go back to the 70’s, but, because marijuana use has been illegal in the United
States since the 30s, research in this field has been largely restricted, and we are still
lacking verifiable evidence of its effects on health. But scientists have been studying its main
chemical components for the treatment of many medical issues, like the nausea caused by
cancer treatments, seizures in children, pain and different sleep disorders. Before we get into how it affects your sleep,
we should probably talk about how it all works. What we call weed, pot, or marijuana is actually
a mixture of the dried flowers of the Cannabis sativa plant. It can be smoked, vaped, brewed in teas, made
into foods, or concentrated into resins and oils. No matter how you take it, the chemicals in
the plant will make their way into your bloodstream, travel throughout your body, and end up in
your brain. How fast you feel the effects and how strong
they are depends on the method of ingestion. And your experiences can range from relaxation
and euphoria, to anxiety, fear and panic depending on how much you take and the potency
of the drug’s active chemicals., Some who have taken large doses have even experienced
a temporary psychosis, including hallucinations and delusions. So it’s really, really important to be careful
with how much you’re taking and how. And cannabis use has been associated with
harmful side effects on brain development and the lungs, and can even result in addiction. The main chemical in cannabis is delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol
- but you can call it THC. THC is a psychoactive chemical, which means
that it can alter your mind. It does this by attaching to neurons in your
brain and activating them. This disrupts normal mental and physical functions,
causing the sensations typically associated a “high”. Cannabis also contains another chemical that
is not psychoactive, called cannabidiol, or CBD. Older studies looking at the effect of the
whole cannabis plant on sleep had mixed findings, with some indicating that it can help you
fall asleep faster and stay asleep, and others showing it can decrease REM sleep,, - which
is thought to be involved with storing memories, learning, and regulating your mood. More recent studies focus on these major chemicals
in cannabis, THC and CBD. They found that THC may only have a short-term
benefit, with continuous use causing a habit or dependency, as withdrawal from the drug
can cause difficulties sleeping.,, Studies also found that THC caused daytime
sleepiness and bad moods, increased the time to fall asleep, and reduced the body’s circadian
rhythm - which is needed to regulate your sleep/wake cycle. However, medicines made from it could help
with certain sleep disorders like nightmares associated with post-traumatic stress disorder
and obstructive sleep apnea. It’s clear that more research needs to be
done before any definitive conclusions can be made. But, until then, it may be better to stick
to natural sleep methods like avoiding caffeine, exercising, and keeping a regular sleep schedule.
